On Mon, 6 Jan 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> 1) Use HEAD to determine if the contents have changed.  This keeps you from
> having to get the entire resource.

No doubt the contents have changed.  The issue is
that since I know the contents simply grow, if I
prohibited the server from changing URLs, I could
retrieve only the new messages by using range
headers to retrieve all content beyond the
content-length I have received so far.

The problem here is how to retrieve only the new
messages if the length of old messages changes
(perhaps because of changes in the length of the
URLs to which the metadata points).

> 2) There is nothing in REST that says the URI must identify a specific
> directory location.  As a result, you could create the necessary URIs up
> front and just keep an internal map to the actual location.  If the server
> wants to move an attachment, it just needs to update the map.  The URI will
> still "point to"  the attachment (i.e. the resource/representation isn't any
> different).  If you are doing this across multiple web servers, you could
> also use the map table to instead return an appropriate HTTP 301 "Moved
> Permanently" or 302 "Found" to redirect the client to the actual URI.

I'm not sure I understand what you mean.  I
suppose I could commit to a metadata format that
does not actually include the actual URL but
intead includes the URL of a redirect to the
actual URL, but that doubles server round trips
and I would like to avoid that as well.

> 3) I am uneasy about the range feature of HTTP.  It doesn't feel very
> extensible to me (e.g. if you message format changed, range calculations
> would have to change as well).

Yes, that is exactly why range headers don't
appear to be an answer to the question I am
asking.

> 4) (this is more of a question to the whole list) Would it be RESTful to
> maintain a resource whose response to a GET only contained the new items?
> For instance, suppose after each successful GET of a mail message, the
> client were to POST the URI to this resource.  On a GET of this resource,
> the server would return all message URIs for which it had not been notified
> of by the POST(s).  This technique would also obviate the need for the HTTP
> range technique.

Hmm, this looks interesting.  A variant of this
proposal would be for the server to return the URL
at which it will serve the next set of messages
even if those messages don't yet exist... I'm not
sure how RESTful that would be either.
